title: Day 875
content:
# Day 875

**Finding Joy in the Simple Things**

I've stumbled upon a little secret lately: consistent exercise and increased prayer have brought an unexpected wave of joy into my life. It's funny how these basic practices can pack such a punch. They've got me thinking about what really matters.

You know, I've noticed that truly enriching experiences feed my soul, while empty pursuits leave me feeling hollow. It's made me take a hard look at my habits. If something I do regularly isn't satisfying me, maybe it's time to shake things up.

Just yesterday, I called an old friend out of the blue. Turns out, they really needed to hear from me. That conversation was greatâ€” a reminder that relationships need tending. Friendships are living things. Neglect them, and they wither, but give them a little attention, and wow, do they bloom.

Life's been throwing some curveballs my way too. I've picked up on this weird pattern: the more I desperately want something, the further away it seems to get. It's like chasing a mirage. But when I manage to adopt a "whatever happens, happens" mindset, things start falling into place. The universe has a twisted sense of humor, I swear.

I'm learning that to get what I want, sometimes I need to ease up on wanting it so badly. It's counterintuitive, like the Chinese finger traps from childhood. The harder you pull, the tighter it grips. The trick is to relax and let go.

On a different note, I went to an AI meetup tonight. We dove into open-source licenses and their implications for AI models. It sparked an intriguing thought: if an AI trained on proprietary code generates similar but distinct code, is that really theft? I'm inclined to say no, but it seems the legal world is salivating over these murky waters. The whole situation reminds me of how technology often outpaces our ability to regulate it. By the time the courts hash out these cases, the tech landscape might be unrecognizable. It's like trying to apply horse-and-buggy laws to self-driving cars. We're in this weird limbo where innovation is sprinting ahead while the law is barely out of the starting blocks. I can't help but wonder if we need a completely new framework for thinking about AI and intellectual property, rather than trying to shoehorn it into existing legal structures.

Despite not knowing anyone at the meetup tongiht, I chatted with a few folks and even handed out my business card to one. Who knows? Maybe that person will use Bitcoin to preserve their purchasing power for many years to come. Anyways, here's to finding that balance - in exercise, in prayer, in friendships, and even in the complex world of AI. The big man has a plan for it all.

![I have Faith](https://miro.medium.com/1*lSBhjl3RpBNrG2S9FKQQHQ.png)

8/13/24

Conor Jay Chepenik
